unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain anatomical and physiological changes that occur in common gastrointestinal diseases.
Describe the anatomy of the gastrointestinal system, including structural components and structural organisation of the abdominopelvic wall and viscera.
Describe the hormonal mechanisms that regulate food intake and metabolism.
Describe the pathways involved in the metabolism of glucose, fatty acids and amino acids.
Describe the physiology of the gastrointestinal system, including regulation of motility, secretory function and absorption.

Discuss case studies by organising and integrating knowledge of gastrointestinal structures and functions (as well as concepts of pathophysiology) and by critically evaluating evidence from scientific and medical literature.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Ongoing weekly study to consolidate learning and prepare for each scheduled class.

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to BClinSc and (HLTH108 or ANAT1001) and (MEDI209 or MEDI219 or MEDI2200)

assessments.description: In class practical test assessing integrated anatomy and physiology knowledge of the alimentary system.
Formal written exam using a combination of question types assessing content delivered across the session. This task is completed under examination conditions during the University examination period.
Creation of a three minute video that provides a newly diagnosed patient with relevant medical and scientific information about the disease.
Online quiz assessing integrated knowledge of anatomy and physiology (MCQ, problem solving questions)

data.description: In this unit you will develop an in depth understanding of the anatomy, physiology and biochemistry of the alimentary system. You will be provided with a unique learning experience that encompasses anatomy wet laboratory sessions, simulation laboratory classes, and interactive tutorials. Gross and surface anatomy will be taught alongside gastrointestinal physiology and the major metabolic pathways (carbohydrate, protein and fatty acid metabolism). You will engage in clinical problem solving supported by relevant medical and scientific literature and discuss the ways in which scientific advances translate into clinical practice.
